## Health Centre

### About us

The Health Centre of Northern Provincial Affiliated University College (NPAUC) was established in 1992 and was functioning at Kurumankadu. Later in 1997, NPAUC became the Vavuniya Campus of the University of Jaffna, and health centres were functioning in two locations: one at Park Road, Vavuniya, and the other at the Pampaimadu campus premises. Visiting MOs and part-time health service assistants were treating students and staff for ailments and referring patients to General Hospital Vavuniya for further treatment. The University Health Centre, which is headed by a Chief Medical Officer/University Medical Officer (UMO), is responsible for providing medical care to students and staff of the university. Permanent UMO is appointed to the health centre of the Vavuniya Campus of the University of Jaffna in 2021.

University Health Services is established to provide healthcare facilities to the employees and students attached to the university. The Health Centre is the service point for providing health care services at the university, where preventive and curative services are provided in order to promote healthy living. All university students and staff are entitled to get free consultation and treatment at this centre.

![Picture of Dr. M. Mahendran (MBBS, MCGP, DFM, Family Physician)](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Doctor-Mahendran.jpg)

##### Dr. M. Mahendran (MBBS, MCGP, DFM, Family Physician)

(Visiting)

## Services

- Curative health care services to students and staff
- Preventive health care: health education, vaccinations, etc.
- Medical counseling
- Issuing medical certificates to students & staff
- Referring patients to the hospitals if necessary
- Monitoring food quality and hygiene in canteens and related areas.
- Oral health care services
- Eye clinic, refraction services.

## Future Plans

- Dental & oral care services
- Laboratory facilities
- Health promotion services

## Research Committee of the University of Vavuniya

### About us

The University Research Committee of the University of Vavuniya (UoV) was established in September 2021 as per Section 46 (6) (vii) of the Universities Act No. 16 of 1978. The purpose of the committee is to promote research, scholarship and innovations to the researchers of the UoV in multidisciplinary fields, ensure ethical standards and facilitate the dissemination of the research outcomes at local, national and international levels. Further, it promotes contribution towards regional and national development through nurturing a knowledge-based society with better understanding towards sustainable development.

## Centre for International Affairs

### About the Centre

The rate of internationalisation is growing rapidly all over the world, with unhindered communication channels and inexpensive travel. International relationships in higher education are important since they lead to innovations in knowledge, the free exchange of ideas, and enduring bonds between institutions and industries. Universities across the world are seeking to make the most of the possibilities by forming global partnerships and fostering relationships with other institutions.

In this background, the International Division of the University of Vavuniya was established in October 2021 to enrich the academic, economic, and cultural dimensions of the University by establishing international collaborations with individuals and institutions. The international division is operating under the direct guidance of the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Vavuniya. The International Division will develop long-term and sustainable collaborative activities for all disciplines of the University and will be responsible for planning, managing, and promoting international relations with foreign universities, research institutes, Consulates/Embassies, industries, and other networks. Also, this Division will be in charge of welcoming international students, delegations and guests.

The proposed International Division of the University of Vavuniya will engage its activities in three major aspects: Research, Teaching, and Students’ activities. In terms of research, the division will expect to develop collaborative research programs and global student group projects with foreign universities. About teaching, the International Division will prepare the students for careers in a global economy through the international collaborative training programmes, workshops and student exchange programmes. From the student’s perspective, the proposed Division will expose the student’s talents and promote their ideas with other universities and industries. In addition, the division will be expected to facilitate international students’ activities at the University of Vavuniya. In future, the proposed International Division will facilitate collaborative degrees such as joint and split undergraduate and postgraduate degree programmes.

## Objectives

Objectives 1

Develop the relationship with local and international universities, research institutes, and industries to enrich the teaching, research, and entrepreneurial activities.

Objectives 2

Create opportunities to exchange the local and international academia, research scholars and students.

Objectives 3

Contribute to the achieve the international standards in research and teaching.

Objectives 4

Provide the guidance and coordination for the international students.

Objectives 5

Facilitate the international research conferences, workshops and training programs, and seminars in the University with the collaboration of local and international institutions.

Objectives 6

Maintain good relationship with overseas Alumni.

## Harmony Centre

### About the Centre

Welcome to the official website of the Harmony Centre University of Vavuniya. Harmony Centre is established for building a greater network, more cohesive and resilient platform among students, staff members and communities through interreligious, cultural and societal engagement.

The Harmony Centre of the University of Vavuniya was established on 25th September 2021 as a leading Centre with the vision of “To be a leading center of excellence in creating inter and intra harmony amongst diverse groups for sustainable change”.

The Harmony Center is promoting Learning  to increase awareness of the diverse ethnic and religious traditions, Training to build capacity in varied discussion and involvement, and Engaging  to foster communication and interactions between individuals, groups, and communities, foster peace, and support local and global development.

## Vision

In keeping with the Vision of the University of Vavuniya, the ‘Harmony Centre’ strive **“to be a leading center of excellence in creating inter and intra harmony amongst diverse groups for sustainable change****”**

## Mission

The **Mission** of the Centre is to be a facilitator

- To promote inter-ethnic, intercultural, and inter-religious interactions for peaceful living (**Training**)

- To deepen understanding of the different ethnics & religious cultures ( **Learning**)

- To build bridges and relationships among the groups and communities and create the harmony and sustain the regional and national development ( **Engagement**)

## ICHR 2022

![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/ichr2022.jpg)

The first International Conference on Harmony and Reconciliation 2023 (ICHR 2023) was held on 19 and 20 January, hosted by the Harmony Centre, University of Vavuniya, on the theme of ‘Harmony and Development through Knowledge and Innovation towards Nation Building’.

The central purpose of the centre is to promote understanding of different religious and ethnicities within an academic setting that takes into consideration both the theory and the practice. It seeks to promote the Sri Lankan sprit as opposed to parochial identities and recognises that the message of harmony and reconciliation is relevant today and thereby the need to formulate multi-dimensional approaches to conflict resolution in alignment with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development promoted by the United Nations.

The Vavuniya University seeks to pursue this endeavour through the Harmony Centre, supported by academic and cultural diversification aimed at developing sustainable research that compliments the theoretical as well as the practical from multidimensional global as well as local perspectives.

Under the initiation, planning and direction of University of Vavuniya Vice Chancellor Prof. T. Mangaleswaran, the ICHR 2023 academic conference was held to set a base to reflect on the theme of harmony as relevant to Sri Lankan youth, academia and the wider public.

The conference focused on national unity, development and reconciliation from historical, traditional, theological, economic, social, cultural, political, educational, environmental and other perspectives.

Among the local and international research scholars, experts, artists, religious leaders, devotees and practitioners who attended the two day event which had both academic and cultural aspects, included the Chief Guest, Senior Professor Sujeewa Amarasena who is the current Vice Chancellor of Ruhuna University, Prof. T. Jeyasingham, former Vice Chancellor of the Eastern University of Sri Lanka, Prof. Mohammed Abu Nimer, Director of the Peacebuilding and Development Institute of the American University in Washington, Emeritus Prof. Savitri W.E. Goonesekera, former Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo, Prof. Rajib Timalsina, Assistant Professor, Department of Conflict, Peace and Development Studies of the Tribhuvan University in Nepal, Prof. Svanibor Hubert Pettan, Chair of the Study group on music and minorities of the University of Ljubljana in Slovenia and Dr. Senthan Selvarajah, Co-director, Centre for Media, Human Rights and Peacebuilding in London and the Gate Foundation in UK. Speaking at the conference inaugural session, Professor Sujeewa Amarasena drew upon the urgent need of making education relevant in Sri Lanka and used as an example the recent murder of a university student by another as an indication to show that violence is in the psyche of especially the population.

From his role as a medical doctor and humanist, he spoke of the ideal contribution academia and the overall education system can make towards developing an intellectual framework for objective analysis which he pointed out was needed for pragmatic development of a nation.

He described the 1st International Conference on Harmony and Reconciliation 2023 as contributing to creating such a foundation stating that the challenge is not so much winning a war but winning the peace.

“Winning a war is easy. But it is winning the peace that is difficult. For winning the peace there must be contribution from across sectors and this is what we must work towards,” Prof. Sujeewa Amarasena stated adding that the youth of tomorrow should be adept at winning peace and harmony; first within themselves and then the outer world. Thereby he noted that the education system should focus on establishing the inner and outer harmony of individuals so as to lay fertile ground for wise, empathetic understanding which is needed to make intelligence and intellect work positively.

The former Vice Chancellor of the Eastern University of Sri Lanka, Prof. T. Jeyasingam analysed the definition of harmony within humans from the lens of the mother earth and all which live within its bosom. He spoke of the very essence of harmony as lying within the heart of nature noting that much could be done to create peace within human hearts by using this harmony between earth and humans. There is much to do within the education system to set about innovation in this regard, he noted. “Much potential exists to look widely at how to build harmony with nature and link this to nationbuilding to determine that our futures are truly sustainable and that we are healthy in mind and body,” Prof. Jeyasingam stated.

“The earth and all the space around it, the air, especially has come under the negative influence of man. We must understand that human development should go aligned with nature and not against it,” Prof. Jeyasingam said.

“Have we understood that we are just a smallest fragment of nature? With all our expertise what can we do when nature strikes? What could we do in the tsunami? What can we do against a cyclone? A lifetime of expertise of man faces just a minute of nature’s wrath and we become utterly helpless. Nature takes only few minutes to strike us into a helpless state. After such an event – say for example the tsunami we faced, see how nature went back to its usual calm,” he said.

“Fifteen minutes after the 2004 December tsunami, I closely observed the sea. It had gone back to normal. No one would ever believe that what had occurred had happened and that hundreds had been killed by the sea.”

“Humans must realise that harmony is a concept that is applicable to nature and man in unison. We cannot do terrible things to either nature or man and expect harmony to reign. We have to think. We have to act with deep thinking,” Prof. Jeyasingam stated. He also mentioned the existence of Mother Nature in pristine condition in segments of the land of the Vavuniya University which are nature conservation areas and commented on the many options for nature-based tourism within the university.

Such productive initiatives are those that could be conceptualised as follow up practical project activities connected to the ICHR 2023 academic conference, he noted. Professor Mohammed Abu-Nimer of the American University, School of International Service in International Peace and Conflict Resolution in Washington, DC, in his keynote address spoke of the international perspective connected with conflict resolution which is now a global academic discipline. He focused on both of the theory and the practice, describing conflict resolution as a fundamental requisite for credible human development. Within this macro framework he stated that the core need is for nurturing human linkage and individual transformation, pointing out that this is the micro element that influences and propels larger scale social systems positively.

Emeritus Prof. Savitri E.W. Goonesekera, former Vice Chancellor of the University of Colombo spoke in depth of the interpretation of justice and its relevance. There were panel discussions and presentations of academic research papers covering many aspects of harmony, unity, peacebuilding and sustainable development.

The schedule of conference activities had two key components which comprised of the research sessions and the Harmony Exhibition. The research sessions were designed to focus less on paper reading and lectures but instead the format was geared towards deeper insights into a topic.

The research sessions featured in the conference consisted of two types; the panel sessions and the discussion platform where the panel session was on the practice segment and the discussion was based on the theoretics. The panel sessions conducted concurrently at the conference venue provided an opportunity for multiple presenters to speak on common themes of the conference. Presentations by the panellists were followed by question and answer sessions that opened up to the audience of academics.

The discussion sessions were designed to provide an in-depth look at a specific conference topicfrom one person’s research or practice. Each session followed an interview format in which a moderator interviewed an expert to explore his/her work, knowledge and personal stories. The moderator also engaged the audience in questions and comments.

Together with high quality and innovative research, the conference hosted a harmony show featuring exhibition of art and entrepreneurship, especially by women. The art exhibition had many artists, especially youth presenting work of peace, harmony and reconciliation through their visual stories.

**Conflict resolution and peace building**

Some of the conference themes included Social Cohesion and Reconciliation for Development, Communal Harmony and Social Development, Unity of Diversity towards Nation Building, Peace and Sustainable Development, Harmony with Nature, Role of Art and Culture in Peace Building, Role of Digital Media toward Peace Building, Literature for Peace and Strategic Partnerships for sustainable development.

The conference delegates attended a reception and cultural events hosted by the organisers which represented musical and dance based talents of youth and children of Vavuniya as well as the university. Vavuniya University is multicultural in an essence and is represented by Sri Lankan Tamil, Sinhala and Muslim students.

The Weekend FT and the Harmony page will be publishing detailed stories in the weeks to come connected with the academic and practice based deliberations made at the ICHR conference.

## Staff Development Centre

### About the Centre

The University Grants Commission had initiated the establishment of Staff Development Centres in all universities to undertake the activities that provide opportunities for the growth and career development of all categories of staff by facilitating the acquisition of post-recruitment qualifications for confirmation and promotion; service-specific advanced knowledge and skills through in-service training; and the knowledge of current global trends towards their sustainability in the career, which would uplift the quality of the nation.

## Vision

To be a centre of excellence in training for the development of efficient and effective personnel who could contribute significantly to their institution’s growth and development.

## Mission

To conduct and nurture activities that would promote and contribute to capacity building of staff of the University of Vavuniya.

## Goals

- To provide employees’ orientation training to all categories of newly recruited staff of the university.
- To train the academic staff members of the university in teaching methodologies to attain high academic accreditation nationally and internationally.
- To train academic and administrative staff members on research management, which would lead them to be active contributors to a rich research culture.
- To train in the development of computer-based learning material for conventional, open, and distance learning modes.
- To provide training assistance to improve human relationships at workplaces in a workforce.
- To maintain gender equity and equality among the staff
- To enhance the knowledge of ‘soft skills’ among the staff for their career development.

## Functions of SDC

- To identify the needs for staff development.
- To organise in-house programs for widely required training.
- To make staff aware of external training programs.
- To award certificates of participation and completion for in-house training programs.
- To conduct employee orientation programs for newly recruited academic, administrative, and non-academic staff.

## Centre for Gender Equality & Equity

### About the Centre

At the University of Vavuniya, we are dedicated to fostering a socially and gender-sensitive environment that champions freedom and security. Our goal is to ensure that every student and staff member can pursue their academic and professional aspirations without facing discrimination or oppression.

The Centre for Gender Equity and Equality (CGEE) at the University of Vavuniya is committed to cultivating an inclusive culture that upholds the dignity and rights of all. We strive to promote equality between women and men, eliminate unlawful discrimination and harassment, and create a supportive environment where everyone can reach their full potential.

Through the establishment of a gender-sensitive university culture, we aim to provide a safe and empowering space for all members of our community, ensuring that equality and respect are at the heart of everything we do.

![Picture of Dr. R.Nagulan](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Untitled-design-2-225x300.png)

## Key Functionalities

Policy Development & Implementation

- Formulating gender policies for the university.
- Ensuring compliance with national gender equality guidelines.
- Monitoring and evaluating gender-related initiatives.

Awareness & Capacity Building

- Conducting gender sensitization workshops for students and staff.
- Organizing seminars, training sessions, and discussions on gender equity.
- Promoting awareness of gender-based violence, harassment, and discrimination.

Support Services

- Providing counseling and support for students and staff facing gender-related challenges.
- Establishing complaint mechanisms for gender-based issues.
- Collaborating with legal and psychological support units.

Research & Advocacy

- Conducting research on gender-related topics within the university and community.
- Advocating for gender-inclusive policies at institutional and national levels.
- Publishing reports and articles on gender equality and equity.

Promoting Equal Opportunities

- Encouraging gender balance in leadership and decision-making roles.
- Ensuring equal access to education, resources, and employment opportunities.
- Supporting initiatives for women’s empowerment in academia and beyond.

Community Engagement & Outreach

- Partnering with local and international organizations to advance gender equality.
- Conducting outreach programs to promote gender awareness in society.
- Encouraging student involvement in gender-related social initiatives.

[Home](https://vau.ac.lk/cultural_centre/) [Mgmt Commitee](https://vau.ac.lk/cc_commitee) [News & Events](https://vau.ac.lk/cc_events) [Russian Centre](https://vau.ac.lk/cc_russian) ## Cultural Centre ### About the Centre Sri Lankan culture is a dynamic, challenging, and independent force based on the freedom of expression. Therefore, everyone is to have the opportunity to participate in cultural life and develop society in creativity, diversity, and artistic quality that are integral parts of arts and culture. Therefore, this will develop and promote the rich diversity and uniqueness of various arts of the Zone and upgrade and enrich the people’s consciousness about their cultural heritage. The main objectives of establishing the Arts and Culture Centre are: - To develop the students’ creative potential in culture - To arrange cultural programs through international research and conferences,        seminars, workshops, and training programmes - To encourage understanding between different communities and cultures. - To strengthen personal and collective identity in culture - To inspire the development of interdisciplinary knowledge, skills, and                        competencies in culture - To receive global assistance in developing students’ cultural potential - To facilitate the publications through the Cultural Centre - To share the advanced knowledge of culture through collaboration with the              Government, Non-Government, and International Organizations - To preserve the cultural heritage of multicultural communities - To create an archive to preserve the documents of communities and share              them with the next generation. ![Picture of Ms.S.Subaramya

Steer the Arts and Cultural Centre at the Faculty level to organize the annual programmes effectively. Arrange seminars and workshops on the arts and culture having outside resources Organize and arrange staging cultural programmes with the participation of students of the university, inter-universities and social agencies from the society. ## Centre of Russian Language and Culture

![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/invitation-1024x802.jpg)

OPENING CEREMONY

Cultural Centre partnering with the International Division of the University of Vavuniya, in collaboration with UI. Y. Yakolev Chuvash State Pedagogical University, Russia, inaugurate the opening of the Centre of Russian Language and Culture at the University of Vavuniya on 15th March, 2023.

Further, the Delegates from the UI. Y. Yakolev Chuvash State Pedagogical University, Russia, along with the officials of the University of Vavuniya, Sri Lanka, partake in this occasion with their inspiring thoughts and commitments.

## Career Guidance Unit

### About us

University Grants Commission, Sri Lanka, established the Career Guidance Unit (CGU) of the University of Vavuniya, Sri Lanka. The CGU functions under the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Vavuniya, and the Director of CGU is responsible for the career guidance programmes, seminars, and workshops based on the needs of the undergraduates. The university’s CGU plays a critical role in preparing students for the work by equipping them with the skills to remain competitive in the global economy and lead meaningful and productive lives. Our University Career Guidance Unit programmers can have a positive impact on our university students’ educational, and career decisions and academic performance.

Further, CGU, helps undergraduates to reflect on their ambitions, interests, qualifications and abilities. It helps them to understand the labour market and education systems and to relate this to what they know about themselves. The CGU activities give guidance to undergraduates to plan and make decisions about work and learning. Based on that knowledge, one can access information about the labour market and educational opportunities by organizing it, systematizing it and retrieving as and when required. CGU would help students to make transitions to the working world. Availability of career guidance facilities can improve the efficiency of the education system enabling those who complete education to find labour. As a result, unemployment among the youth could be lowered since the process can match individual talents and qualifications with the skills and qualifications demanded by employers. Therefore, today’s graduates need to be in a superior position in the area of personal development with better communication skills and the ability to be a team player to build up their competitive advantage in the corporate market to succeed.

We at CGU also provide opportunities for our graduates to secure employment in the reputed public sector and as well as in the private sector companies and thereby set the stage for both graduates and the industry to benefit mutually.

[Home](https://vau.ac.lk/business_linkage) [Events](https://vau.ac.lk/bl_events) [Documents](https://vau.ac.lk/bl_documents) [Committee](https://vau.ac.lk/bl_coordinator) ## University Business Linkage ### About us Universities are a source for knowledge, invention, and innovation. Research can create useful products and services as well as find solutions for existing problems faced by society. Therefore, the University of Vavuniya (UoV) motivates faculty members, other employees, and students to engage in the creation and dissemination of knowledge, including inventions, discoveries, and tangible properties arising from research conducted as a part of the educational process. These findings can be used to enlarge the economic capacity of the surrounding region and serve to improve the well-being of the nation. The primary intention of establishing UBL is to support business enterprises in the surrounding region by giving consultancy services, technology transfer, and finding solutions for the existing problems through research and innovation using the permitted university resources. UBL of University of Vavuniya is established on 1st October 2021 under the directive given by the University Grants Commission’s Commission Circular No. 10/2016, dated 25 July 2016 ![Picture of Mrs. S. Mathivathany
Director ](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/mathivathany-150X150-300x300.jpg) #### Mrs. S. Mathivathany Director T.P: 024 222 2265 ### CONTACT US We’re here to assist you. Feel free to reach out using the below details. ### REACH US University of Vavuniya, Pampaimadu, Mannar Road, Vavuniya Sri Lanka Email :ubl@vau.ac.lk Tel : +94 24 222 2265 ![key-functionalaties-of-establishment-branch](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/Key-Functionalaties-1.png) ## Constitution and abbreviation Universities are a source for creativity, knowledge, invention and innovation. Research can lead to the creation of useful new products and services as well as finding solutions to solve problems faced by society. With this as the context, the University Business Linkage – Vavuniya is established to facilitate the identification or creation and exploitation of new IP and to assist in technology transfer from academia to the business community in the region and beyond so that benefits and revenues arising from these can contribute to regional regeneration and economic growth. Hereafter, the University Business Linkage cell at the University of Vavuniya is referred to as “UBL Vavuniya”. ## Vision To become the inspirational epi-centre for new ideas and research that can result in the economic upliftment of the region. ## Mission To become the inspirational epi-centre for new ideas and research that can result in the economic upliftment of the region. ## Objective 1. Motivate the staff and students to initiate business-orientated projects that can be developed into business startups. 2. Coordinate the university’s laboratory/classroom-generated research and provide support for the translation of research outcomes into industry-ready, value-added products and services. 3. Develop entrepreneurial and intrapreneurial skills among staff, students, and the community. 4. Support startup businesses at the university. 5. Facilitate the protection of research findings and all other intellectual property rights. 6. Increase university–industry collaborations. #### UNIVERSITY - [About Us](https://vau.ac.lk/vision-mission/) - [Contact Us](https://vau.ac.lk/contact-us/) - [History](https://vau.ac.lk/history/) - [Chancellor](https://vau.ac.lk/chancellor/) - [Vice chancellor](https://vau.ac.lk/vice-chancellor/) #### ACADEMIC - Faculties - [Library](https://www.vau.ac.lk/library/) - Departments - Centres and Units #### COURSES - Undergraduate - Certificate - [Online](https://www.vau.ac.lk/vle/) #### RESEARCH - Researchers - Research News - Research Repositories - [Staff in Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&view_op=search_authors&mauthors=%22vau.ac.lk%22) - Awards & Prizes - Research Grants #### EXTERNAL LINKS - [Research Gate](https://www.researchgate.net/institution/University-of-Vavuniya/members) - [Ragging / CGEE Complaints Portal](https://eugc.ugc.ac.lk/complaint-portal/) - [University Grants Commission](https://www.ugc.ac.lk/) - [NFS Global Digital Platform (GDP)](https://gdp.nsf.gov.lk/) - [Ministry of Higher Education](https://www.mohe.gov.lk/index.php?lang=en) ###### © 2025 University of Vavuniya, Sri Lanka. ## Young Inventor's Club

### About Us

The Sri Lanka Inventors Commission established the Young Inventors Club, University of Vavuniya, in September 2021 (Circular No. SLIC/PROJ/INVCLUB-2021) to enhance the innovative culture and creativity among students. This facilitates the students’ engaging in research works in finding solutions for prevailing problems faced by the society, as well as motivating the students to construct new ideas more openly and with innovation. Thereby, this will improve the wellbeing of the society and moreover contribute to the future national economy.

### CONTACT US

We’re here to assist you.
Feel free to reach out using the below details.

### REACH US

University of Vavuniya,


Pampaimadu,
Mannar Road,
Vavuniya
Sri Lanka

Email :

Tel : +



![key-functionalaties-of-establishment-branch](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/Key-Functionalaties-1.png)

## Objective

1. Promote and encourage creativity among students.
2. Provide opportunities and facilities to unleash their innovations without hindrance.
3. Master the use of students’ understanding of science and technology
4. Involvement of young inventors in innovation and exhibitions
5. Establishment of a reciprocal relationship between the Sri Lanka Inventors Commission and the students
6. Facilitate the obtaining of patents for inventions, focusing on research opportunities and upgrading to prototypes based on relative merit
7. Introduce the practical application of scientific theories and the importance of producing innovations of commercial value

##### General Guideline

Library Guidelines

## General Guideline

### 1\. Book Issuing

| Sections | Time (Issue) | Time (Return) | Duration for Students | Duration for Academic Staff | Duration for Non-Academic Staff |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Reference section | 3.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. | 8.30 a.m. to 9.00 a.m. | 1 Day | 1 Week | - |
| Stack section | 8.00 a.m. to 6.00 p.m. | 8.00 a.m. to 6.00 p.m. | 1 Week | 1 Month | 1 Week |

### 2\. Loan Limits

| Sections | 1st Year | 2nd Year | 3rd Year | 4th Year | Academic Staff (Permanent) | Academic Staff (Temporary) | Non-Academic Staff |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Reference section | 01 | 01 | 01 | 01 | 02 | 02 | - |
| Stack section | 02 | 03 | 04 | 04 | 06 | 02 | 02 |
| **Total** | **03** | **04** | **05** | **05** | **08** | **04** | **02** |

### 3\. Fines

| Type of the Book | Per Day Fine |
| --- | --- |
| Reference section | Rs 50.00 |
| Stack section | Rs 05.00 |

### 4\. Renewal Book

Users are permitted to renew their books before the due date, with a maximum of two renewals allowed per book.

### 5\. GENERAL RULES

**Valued Readers,**

- It is a great pleasure to welcome you.
- We look forward to satisfying your thirst for knowledge to the best of our abilities.
- Please avoid standing in front of or around the reception desk.
- Silence must be observed at all times inside the library.
- Switch off your mobile phones upon entering the library.
- Do not bring briefcases, handbags, file covers, umbrellas, hats, diaries, personal books, or similar items into the library.
- CR books, exercise books, personal books, and bulk sheets are not permitted inside the library.
- Please declare all your materials at the counter when entering and leaving the library.
- Readers are not expected to shelve books; please keep them neatly on the table.
- Books should not be taken from one section to another.
- Smoking, consumption of food, and carrying water bottles are strictly prohibited inside the library.
- Readers must submit their student identity cards, books, and papers for inspection upon request by library staff.
- Acts of misconduct may result in suspension of library membership.
- Do not take uncharged books out of the library premises; this is a punishable offense.
- Charged books should not be brought back into the library except for discharge.
- Group discussions inside the library are not permitted.

- Do not leave any valuable articles or cash unattended outside the library. The library is not
responsible for any losses.

Readers are kindly expected to abide by these rules and regulations. Violation of library rules may
lead to cancellation or suspension of library membership. These rules are as effective as the
University regulations.


##### Collections

[![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/VANNI-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3ABP&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AVC&sort_by=relevance)

Vaani book collection, often used in the context of spirituality or literary works, typically refers to a collection of writings, poems, or teachings attributed to a particular individual or tradition.

[![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Srilankan-2-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3ASLC&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AVC&sort_by=relevance)

The Sri Lanka Collection is a distinguished assemblage that preserves the island’s rich cultural heritage, historical narratives, and literary traditions.

[![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/bOUND-1-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3ABP&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AVC&sort_by=relevance)

A bound periodical is a collection of individual issues of a serial publication that have been physically compiled and bound together into volumes for preservation and easier reference.

[![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/pERMANENT-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AREF&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AVC&sort_by=relevance)

Permanent references are carefully curated collections of authoritative, non-circulating materials maintained by libraries and research institutions for ongoing study, consultation, and research purposes

[![library_reference](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/id-7-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AREF&sort_by=relevance)

Reference books are informational resources that provide facts, data, or concise overviews on various subjects. Unlike textbooks, they are not meant to be read cover-to-cover but used to find specific information quickly.

[![](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/LENDING-150x150.jpg)](http://lib.vau.ac.lk/cgi-bin/koha/opac-search.pl?advsearch=1&do=Search&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3ABP&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3ABK&limit=mc-itype%2Cphr%3AVC&sort_by=relevance)

A lending book is a book that is part of a library's circulating collection, meaning it can be borrowed by library users and taken home for a specified loan period, typically a few weeks.

### Photocopying Service

The photocopying service operated in the library is located on the left side of the entrance of the main library. Similar services are available in other faculty library premises as well.

### Apply online for ISBN/ISSN/ISMN

#### University Publications

A UNIVERSITY ACCOUNT created by the library is required to apply online for ISBN/ISSN/ISMN for university publications.

Please contact the following library staff for further information.

## Examination Branch

### About the Branch

All the internal examination affairs of the University of Vavuniya are coordinated and conducted by the Examination  Branch. The Recruitment examinations, Confirmation and Promotion examinations for the non-academic, Academic Supportive staff are also conducted by the branch. Further Examination Branch issues Degree certificates, detailed results, Statements and Academic Transcripts for all undergraduate students. The Confirmation of degrees which are referred from various government and private organizations is carried out by the branch per their request. The Examination Branch prepares and provides a list of graduates for the convocation.

The Examination and Student Admission Branch also enrolls students and issues record books and identity cards for them.

## Physical Education Unit

### About us

The Physical Education Unit is a service unit that promotes sports and recreational activities among students and staff at the University of Vavuniya. The Physical Education Unit has the facilities for all the sports and recreational activities. Also, it provides services to the community by providing sports venues.

![Picture of Mr. R. Sivasegaran](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/R.Sivasegaran-Instructor-in-Phy.-Edu-Gr-II-300x300.jpg)

To engage in relentless pursuit of excellence in promoting and developing physical education and sports through innovative programs in coaching and outreach activities. And evolve a holistic approach to the betterment of human resources through a harmonious blend of body, mind, and spirit.

## Senate Members

The university shall have a Senate which shall be the academic authority of the University. Section 46 of the Universities Act defines the composition, powers, duties and functions of the Senate.

The Senate of the University shall consist of the following persons

- The Vice-Chancellor;
- The Deputy Vice-Chancellor, if any;
- The Rector of each Campus, if any;
- The Director of each Institute or Centre for Higher Learning, if any, affiliated to the University;
- The Dean of the Faculty of Graduate Studies, if any;
- The Dean of each Faculty;
- The Head of each Department of Study;
- Every permanent Professor of the University;
- The Librarian; and
- Two teachers, other than those referred to above, are elected by the permanent teachers of each Faculty from among their number

The Senate shall have control and general direction of instruction, education, research and examinations in the University.

- Curriculum and Evaluation Committee
- University Research and Ethics Committee
- Examination Offence Committee
- [Senate Standing Committee on Quality Assurance](https://vau.ac.lk/cqa/index.php/composition-of-cqa/)

Subject to the provisions of the Act as stated in Section 46 (6) of the Act the Senate shall exercise, perform and discharge the following powers, duties and functions

To draft, after consideration of reports from the Faculty Board, Regulations relating to courses of study and examinations and to submit such drafts to the Council for approval;

- To recommend to the Council, after consideration of reports from the Faculty Board/s, the names of persons suitable for appointment as examiners;
- To recommend to the Council the institution, abolition or suspension of Professorships, Associate Professorships, Senior Lectureships, Lectureships, and other academic posts in the University;
- To recommend to the Council after consideration of reports from the Faculty Boards
- Schemes for the reorganisation of existing Faculties and Departments of Study and the organization of new Faculties and Departments of Study; and
- The assignment of subjects of study to the respective Faculties;
- to award fellowships, scholarships, exhibitions, bursaries, medals and other prizes on such conditions as may be approved by the Council;
- to appoint such number of Standing Committees, or Ad-hoc Committees or Boards of the Senate as it may deem fit and in particular:
- Library Committee;
-  Admissions Committee;
- Research Committee;
- Curriculum and Evaluation Committee; and
- Probationary Study Leave Committee; and to specify their terms of reference; to consider their reports and to either approve such reports, whether with or without modification, or to reject such reports; and
- to recommend to the Council requirements for the admission of students to courses of study.

## Internal Audit Unit

### About us

The Internal Audit Division of the University of Vavuniya functions as an independent assurance unit, directly operating under the supervision of the vice-chancellor. Its core purpose is to evaluate and improve the university’s governance, risk management, internal control, and compliance systems. The division plays a vital role in supporting the vice-chancellor, accounting officer, and top management by reviewing systems and procedures to ensure that university operations are conducted in a true, fair, and transparent manner. Through continuous monitoring, review, and advisory services, the Internal Audit Division upholds institutional accountability and promotes good governance across all levels of university operations.

![Picture of Mrs.K.Luxstella](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Devaisy-150X150-4.jpg)

### Objective

Promote Accountability and Transparency

By independently reviewing operations and controls, the division helps ensure that the university adheres to principles of good governance.

Assess and Strengthen Internal Controls

To evaluate the design and effectiveness of internal control systems in detecting and preventing errors, fraud, waste, and inefficiencies.

Monitor Compliance

1. To verify that university operations conform to:

- Financial Regulations of the Government of Sri Lanka
- Circulars issued by the University Grants Commission (UGC)
- University statutes, by-laws, and policies

Support Risk Management

To assist management in identifying, assessing, and mitigating operational, financial, and compliance risks.

Enhance Operational Efficiency

To review systems and procedures with a view to recommending improvements that increase productivity and resource utilization.

Provide Insightful Recommendations

To contribute to informed decision-making through professional, evidence-based

findings and practical suggestions.

# Call for Applications for Research grants – 2026

University of Vavuniya is calling applications for research grants for the year 2026 to promote high quality research among staff. The purpose of the research grants is to facilitate innovative and collaborative research, and to make the research outcomes benefitted to the national development.

1. **Eligibility:** Permanent academic staff members in the university who are eligible for research allowance under the Establishment circular No 5/2014 (i) and 5/2014 (ii) dated 28.05.2014 and 30.05.2014 respectively.
2. **Amount of Fund:** No limit, but strict evaluation of cost versus outcome value.
3. **Period of award:** 12 months, with the possible extension of 6 months
4. **Application process:** Duly filled application forms available on URC website and submit to Head of the Department to reach the URC before the deadline.
5. **Acceptance:** The acceptance will be given after the external review process based on the impact of the research and the quality of the proposal.
6. **Monitoring progress:** Quarterly progress reports should be submitted during the research period. The final report should be submitted at the end of 18 months.

### **Submission Deadline:** 10 th January 2026

### Director's Message

## Centre for Distance & Continuing Education

Welcome to the Centre for Distance and Continuing Education (CDCE), University of Vavuniya. The CDCE was established at the University of Vavuniya in 2023 under the Commission Circular No. 932. The CDCE is committed to expanding access to quality higher education through

flexible and innovative learning pathways. Our mission is to provide lifelong learning opportunities to a diverse community of learners, empowering them with the knowledge and skills needed to thrive in today’s dynamic job market. The CDCE offers a range of extension programmes (Certificates and Diplomas) and external degree programmes, carefully designed to meet current industry demands and enhance professional development. Whether you are a working professional seeking career advancement or a learner looking to acquire new competencies, our programmes are tailored to fit your needs while maintaining academic excellence.

At CDCE, we embrace the latest educational technologies and learner-centric approaches to ensure an engaging and accessible learning experience. Our dedicated faculty and staff are committed to supporting your academic journey every step of the way. I invite you to explore our programmes and join us in shaping a brighter future through education. Together, let’s unlock new opportunities and achieve your academic and professional goals.

## Course Details

Higher Diploma in English

## Overview of the Program

The Higher Diploma in English (HDE) extension program was initiated by the Department of English Language Teaching of the Faculty of Business Studies to extend its academic activities to the public. The need for the new curriculum development of the extension programmes in English is felt indispensable since implementing the SLQF standards fulfilling national and international standards.


A curriculum development committee was formed, and it analyzed stakeholders' requirements and job opportunities. Hence, the new curricula of the extension programmes were carefully developed to meet the recommendation of the curriculum revision and development committee. As a result, the syllabi and the entry requirements were developed on par with the present semester system with fifteen credits per semester. This two-year program is conducted with the optional exit points at the first semester of the first year (Advanced Certificate) and at the end of the first year (Diploma).


The country requires more professionals in the field of English for regional and national development. This English program will increase the employability among the graduates and A/L Education Qualification holders. The higher diploma holders will have high opportunities to find jobs or promote the employed with sufficient competing skills.


## Objectives of the Program

- Students should excel in the structures and functions of the English language skills, linguistic structures, translation skills, and literature.
- Students should understand the grammatical components used in discourse contributing to effective communication and generate sentences creatively and naturally in real context.
- Students should read a significant range of literary/non-literary genres in English and its varieties spoken across the world, apply traditional and modern theories of literary criticism, and demonstrate powers of critical/analytical thinking alongside an appreciation of the crafting of written utterances and the interrelationships between texts.
- Students should perform or create online communication using English discourse clearly and succinctly, analyze and synthesize types of texts, and be trained in writing for real purposes.
- Students should research critically by asking pertinent questions about a text, recognizing assumptions and implications, evaluating ideas, viewing a literary or non-literary text analytically, and seeing relationships between form and content.

## Duration of the Program

Two Years (Part Time)

## Academic Coordinator

Mrs. Sarmatha Priyatharshan

Senior Lecturer Gr II

Department of English Language Teaching (DELT),

Faculty of Business Studies,

University of Vavuniya.

Contact No: 077 415 7414


Diploma in Early Childhood Education

## Overview of the Program

Sri Lanka has Early Childhood Development Standards (ECDS) for three to five-year olds; an essential starting place for quality. However, their acceptance and application as a resource by teachers, parents, and all adults who contribute to children’s education are selective. After the evaluation of the preschool education system, the NEC has recommended policies on Policy Development for quality in preschool education.


Further, it has been reported that Sri Lanka’s patchwork of preschool education standards, curricula, and administration systems has resulted in poor or mediocre learning that fails many children and prevents them from realizing their full potential. A coordinated effort is therefore needed to ensure that the Early Childhood Development Standards (ECDS) are implemented nationwide so that all early childhood children have an equal opportunity to develop the skills and competencies that will prepare them for school life and beyond.


The diploma program at the University of Vavuniya is based on a conceptual framework of current theory and contemporary perspectives. Diploma in Early Childhood Education gives preschool teachers the tools and skills to make an impact in the lives of early childhood learners. Fostering a love of learning in children under the age of five can set them up for success throughout their entire educational journey. Beyond learning academics, early childhood education focuses on social and emotional development and helps early childhood minds to develop a positive outlook on education. This diploma course is designed based on the National Early Childhood Development Standards, which have been prepared as a national curriculum.


## Objectives of the Program

- To provide advanced knowledge, skills, and abilities which are essential to become a successful preschool teacher.
- To develop and strengthen teachers in adapting Early Childhood Development Standards.
- To provide career pathways for preschool teachers towards increasing levels of education, experience, and demonstrated competencies.

## Duration of the Program

15 Months (Part Time)

## Academic Coordinator

Advanced Certificate in Sports Coaching and Physical Education

## Overview of the Program

There is a lack of learning opportunities for Physical Education (PE) teachers, coaches, sports officers, and trainers of many sports in Sri Lanka regarding Sport Education. Among these professionals, PE teachers and coaches face difficulties in achieving higher education qualifications.


The University of Vavuniya (UOV) recognizes the importance of offering sport-related courses to disseminate knowledge to school coaches, physical education teachers, trainers, sports officers, and district sports officers in the area. This will, in turn, have economic and social impacts on the country—specifically in the region—by increasing employment, promoting national unity, encouraging public physical activity, enhancing community relations, and reducing youth crime and healthcare costs.


UOV held a discussion on 29th July 2022 with relevant stakeholders and experts, which revealed a high demand for sport-related education programmes at regional, national, and transitional levels. With access to infrastructure such as a new 400m ground and fully equipped gym, and with sufficient academic staff, UOV is well-positioned to deliver this program. A 20-credit curriculum has been developed by a group of lecturers from the University of Vavuniya and Sabaragamuwa University of Sri Lanka to fulfill regional and national requirements.


## Objectives of the Program

The aim of the course is to train and educate efficient PE teachers, sports coaches, trainers, and physical training instructors actively engaged in the field. It targets PE teachers and sports trainers in schools and training colleges, specializing in Physical Education and Sports Training.


## Learning Outcomes and Profile of Qualification Holder

After completing the course, students will be able to:

- Acquire knowledge about physical and health education.
- Develop skills in organizing physical education programs in schools.
- Develop the activities required for organizing physical education meets and events.
- Acquire knowledge about recreation, health, safety education, and common communicable diseases.
- Understand the nature of injuries and provide first aid.
- Acquire knowledge about physical exercises.
- Create awareness on different aspects of health and fitness.
- Understand diet modification for athletes, under-weight, and obese physiques.

## Duration of the Program

Six Months (Part Time)

Advanced Certificate in Media Literacy and Journalism

## Overview of the Program

The proposed certificate course aims at providing a greater learning opportunity for young budding journalists, journalists already working for established media, potential future journalists, and digital media enthusiasts to widen their professional competency in the fundamentals of digital media consumption.


The course offers a holistic understanding of a wide range of subjects such as media operations in a convergence setting, globally accepted media standards, media ownership, digital media and radicalization, hate speech, media ethics, critical consumption techniques, digital media applications, the complex nature of the media landscape, information falsehood, verification skills, disinformation identification, news literacy basics, agenda setting, and media bias.


Increasing media polarization and misinformation demand journalists to operate with responsibility, responsiveness, and accountability in their profession.


## Objectives of the Program

- To define principles, concepts, theories, and methods related to Media Literacy and Accountable Journalism.
- To identify characteristics of reliable, objective, and fair journalism.
- To tactfully deal with all forms of information falsehood.
- To define the core values of responsive and accountable journalism.
- To articulate what is ethical and solution journalism.
- To explain the relevance of critical media consumption in countering hateful narratives.
- To identify skills of critical information consumption.
- To determine all forms of information falsehood.
- To develop competency in key skills, problem-solving, professional standards, and life-long learning.
- To maintain healthy digital news and information consumption habits.
- To use internet technology with a sense of responsibility and privacy.

## Duration of the Program

Six Months (Part Time)

Certificate in Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management

## Overview of the Program

Creating new entrepreneurs at this juncture of the Sri Lankan economy is a dire requirement, as more of them are important to market economies such as Sri Lanka due to multiple reasons. Entrepreneurs act as the wheels of economic growth in the country, creating wealth and improving social standards. By gaining entry to the market with their innovative ideas and clear goals, new entrepreneurs can immensely help accelerate economic development.


The University of Vavuniya intends to introduce a Certificate Course on Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management to equip students for the future, since the impact of the crisis in our lives is increasing in various needs and wants. This certificate program is mostly targeted at school leavers (Grade 9 or above), because entrepreneurship education teaches essential life skills such as innovative problem-solving, resolving real-world challenges, and teamwork.


Furthermore, entrepreneurship education has emerged as a demanding subject to be mastered by young students. As jobs become more limited due to factors such as technological advancements and population growth, entrepreneurship stands out as a significant and empowering career option among the current generation.


## Objectives of the Program

- To provide a platform for the participants to further explore the field of Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management in their chosen discipline.
- To familiarize the participants with the concept and overview of entrepreneurship and small business management to enhance entrepreneurial talent.
- To impart knowledge on the basics of entrepreneurial skills and competencies to provide inputs for creating new ventures.
- To explore new vistas of entrepreneurship in a 21st-century environment to generate innovative business ideas.

## Duration of the Program

Six Months (Part Time)

## Academic Coordinator

Mr. P. Sasitharan

Course Coordinator

Certificate in Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management

Advanced Certificate in Women Empowerment in Politics

## Overview of the Program

The programme’s main focus is to develop the competencies of women by empowering and building capacity in politics, with the aim of improving relevant knowledge and skills and providing training for women who are aspiring to get involved energetically in politics.


Therefore, the women’s main focus on a career in politics and decision-making organizations is two-fold: acquiring competency in politics and development planning and management, and acquiring competency in the disciplines of Empowerment, Leadership, Democracy, and Governance.


The aim of this programme is **“to provide women with a wide range of knowledge and the ability to effectively manage development programs with good governance in politics”**. The country requires more professional women in the fields of rural, urban, regional, and national development. This Advanced Certificate in Empowering Women in Politics (ACEWP) will increase the employability of women in educational organizations and communities. The certificate holders will have high opportunities to find jobs or gain promotions with sufficient competitive skills.


## Objectives of the Program

- To improve their knowledge of the concept of gender, the importance of women’s participation in politics and decision-making levels, women’s rights, and women’s law, and to develop relevant leadership skills and qualities.
- To increase women's self-knowledge about their values and vision, as well as enhance their capabilities as leaders, managers, and team contributors.
- To help women engage in purposeful career development and take on leadership roles for important causes, to lead change with conviction and confidence, and to improve workplaces and communities for all.

## Duration of the Program

Six Months (Part Time)

Mrs. S. Mathivathany

## Library

### About the Library

The library of the University of Vavuniya plays a vital role in enhancing the staff and students’ teaching, learning, and research experience, providing them with all the information they need to improve their knowledge, skills, and abilities. The library was established in 1992 with the inauguration of Northern Province Affiliated University College. The university library serves all three faculties: the Faculty of Applied Sciences, the Faculty of Business Studies, and the Faculty of Technological Studies.

## Office of Vice Chancellor

#### Message from the Vice-Chancellor

I am very delighted to work with my colleagues as the second Vice Chancellor of the University of Vavuniya. The University of Vavuniya was evolving, starting in 1991 as Northern Provincial Affiliated University College; then, in 1997, it became the Vavuniya Campus of the University of Jaffna. Finally, after thirty years, from 1st August 2021, it has become a university with all the hard work of the former vice chancellor, rectors, deans, registrar, bursar, heads of the departments, professors, and all staff.

The University of Vavuniya is travelling as one of the leading centres of excellence in knowledge advancement and dissemination for sustainable change. The university is also extending its facilities to foster sustainable quality of education and uphold excellence in teaching, learning, and research activities to fill the gaps in the region and nation.

The quality assurance of the teaching and learning process is being strengthened with a complete cycle of analysing the performance and accordingly upgrading. Accordingly, the graduates from the University of Vavuniya are very well trained with expertise in knowledge, skills, and abilities, who can be good citizens and leaders to serve the nation and the world.

With the dedicated team of staff at the University of Vavuniya and volunteering international experts, the university is in the process of utilising the technologies for digitalising its day-to-day administrative operations. This will create an effective and efficient administrative system within the university while reducing any unnecessary delays in its operations.

![Picture of Senior Professor A. Atputharajah ](https://www.vau.ac.lk/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/vc_edited-300x274.png)

#### Senior Professor A. Atputharajah

B.Sc.Eng.(Peradeniya),

Ph.D.(Manchester)

Senior Member of the IEEE,

C.Eng., MIE(SL).

T.P: 024 222 2264

Research, development, commercialisation, producing entrepreneurs, and start-up businesses are the current era. The University of Vavuniya is continuing and dedicating itself to strengthening this direction of development. The university is also welcoming all possible partners to contribute in this regard

The University Business Linkage is strengthened to enhance the university-industry interactions, provide consulting services, disseminate knowledge through CPD programs, and apply the research outcome to the business. This will enhance the direct linkage services with the outside organisations and industries.

The university is also continuing its services with strong collaborations with possible organisations for regional development. The university community is happily enhancing their services in all possible directions for uplifting regional and national developments. All communications for collaborations can be initiated through official channels of the university.

[Professor A. Atputharajah,](https://www.eng.jfn.ac.lk/prof-atpu/) Vice Chancellor of the University of Vavuniya and Senior Professor in Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Jaffna. Currently, he is serving as Vice Chancellor at the University of Vavuniya

## Responsibilities

Strategic Leadership & Policy Development

- Setting the overall direction and vision of the university.
- Developing and approving institutional policies and plans.
- Representing the university at national and international forums.

Academic and Administrative Oversight

- Supervising all academic and non-academic units.
- Approving academic programs and curriculum changes.
- Overseeing staff recruitment, promotions, and appointments.

Governance and Coordination

- Chairing key university councils and boards (e.g., Senate, Council).
- Coordinating with deans, heads of departments, and administrative units.
- Ensuring effective communication between departments and external stakeholders.

External Relations and Representation

- Building relationships with government ministries, UGC , and other institutions.
- Managing donor relations and external partnerships.
- Representing the university in official events, collaborations, and MoUs.

Financial and Resource Management

- Approving and monitoring the university budget (with the Bursar).
- Allocating resources for university projects and activities.
- Ensuring compliance with financial regulations and audits.

Crisis and Conflict Management

- Handling disputes or crises involving students, staff, or university infrastructure.
- Making high-level decisions in emergency situations (e.g., natural disasters, strikes).

Public Communication and Institutional Image

- Delivering speeches, messages, and official statements.
- Leading ceremonial events (e.g., convocations, inaugurations).
- Promoting the university’s reputation and achievements.

Finally, after thirty years, from 1st August 2021, it has become as the University with all hard-works of former Vice Chancellor, Rectors, Deans, Registrar, Bursar, Heads of the Departments, Professors and all staff.

The University of Vavuniya, is being traveling, as one of the leading center of excellence in knowledge advancement and dissemination for sustainable change. The University is also extending its facilities to foster sustainable quality of education and uphold excellence in teaching, learning and research activities to fulfil the gaps in the region and nation.

## Centre for Quality Assurance

### About the Centre

Centre for Quality Assurance (CQA) of the University of Vavuniya was established on 01.10.2021 in compliance with the Commission Circular No.09/2019. CQA’s academic, administrative and financial controls are managed through a standing committee of the Senate of the University of Vavuniya.

The CQA is headed by a Director, who is guided by the standing committee of the Senate. The Senate Standing Committee on Quality Assurance is chaired by the Vice-Chancellor of the University, as per the guidelines issued by the UGC in this regard. The Deputy Registrar, Academic Affairs, as he the Secretary to the Committee. The Faculty level Quality Assurance activities are managed by the Faculty Quality Assurance Cells as per the Quality Assurance By-Laws.

## Vision

To achieve the quality excellence in undergraduate and post graduate degree programmes of the University.

## Mission

Enhance the holistic quality assurance system in all the components of the higher education of the University and sustain the process of continuous improvements for all teaching, learning, research, student support, and community outreach.

## Goal

The goal of the CQA shall be to create a culture that seeks to continually improve the quality of all academic and administrative activities efficiently and effectively in the University.

## Objective

- Promote quality enhancement across the University.
- Guide and support self-evaluation for programme and institutional reviews.
- Facilitate implementation and monitoring of review recommendations.
- Collaborate with other HEIS to share best practices.
- Coordinate with the Quality Assurance Council and UGC for internal/external reviews.
- Institutionalise quality assurance through national and international standards.
- Align university procedures with UGC and national guidelines.
- Strengthen the University’s public image through consistent quality practices.

# Proctor Office

The key functions of the proctor office are to **plan, organize, and implement** all possible preventive measures to minimise **ragging** and all forms of **student misconduct** to help the university realize its mission. The Proctor office, which comes under the direct purview of the Vice Chancellor, maintains student discipline by keeping a twenty-four-hour vigil in the university and monitoring activities and students’ behavior in faculties, centers, hostels, the gymnasium, and playgrounds.
